title: (x) serif type in Swiss DU magazine - DU Serif (customised Palatino) {FlorianCH (Raph)}
content:
Used in a Swiss magazine called DU. Anyone?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Du.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021124605/http:/typophile.com/files/Du.gif) | 16.93 KB |

 [‹ (x) Outback Steakhouse logo - Publicity Gothic, Corintian {Niall Moran}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021124605/http:/typophile.com/node/30609 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Shadowed grotesque in Tate ETC. magazine - Sans Serif Shaded {Brown Fox} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021124605/http:/typophile.com/node/30607 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Brown Fox

comments.content: It’s some version of Palatino, not sure which.
I also had the feeling that it was a Zapf typeface, but the lowercase ’a’ looks considerably different than Palatino. At least the version I know... Maybe some customised version?

The Swiss magazine [«DU»](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021124605/http:/www.dumag.ch/heft.php) doesn’t use a Palatino, but several versions of Bram de Does’ beautiful [Lexicon](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021124605/http:/www.teff.nl/fonts/lexicon/lexicon.html). If you know German: There has been a thread going on about the subject in the German [typoforum](http://web.archive.org/web/20071021124605/http:/www.typografie.info/typoforum/viewtopic.php?t=2205&highlight=lexicon).

«DU», or some of the issues anyway, belongs in my opinion to one of the finest magazines ever.
Well, we’re _definitely_ not looking at Lexicon, but at a version of Palatino. Except for the slightly different lc ’a’ all the other earmarks are there.

Sorry, I was so excited that «DU» has been mentioned that I didn’t even have a look at the sample. Indeed, this doesn’t look like Lexicon – which is used however in every variant throughout «DU». Mixing Lexicon with some Palatino seems a strange choice to me …
Du uses Lexicon for the text, the one i posted for the headings. Is there different versions of Palatino at all?

Palatino is known for having numerous knock-offs, even some created by Zapf himself. It could also be a custom type created for the magazine. My suggestion would be to contact them.

- Lex
I might ask them directly, if you want to. They sit just around the corner.
Now that’s what I’ve been told: It is indeed a customized version of «Palatino», appropriately named **DU-serif** , which apparently should be revised again soon.
